SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What is Pearson's most significant achievement?

A.Choice: He served as president of the UN's General Assembly.

B.Choice: He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957.

C.Choice: He defined what it means to be Canadian.

D.Choice: He was Canada's 14th prime minister.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: What does paragraph 1 emphasize about Lester B. Pearson?

A.Choice: that he is not fully understood for the impact he had on the country

B.Choice: that he is well known for all of his achievements for the country

C.Choice: that he served the country in many different roles

D.Choice: that he utilized unique people to serve the country

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: What claim is made about the relationship between Canada and the United Kingdom before Lester B. Pearson served as Prime Minister in the statement below from paragraph 2?
:ibox:“he helped transform Canada from a colonial appendage to an autonomous state with a powerful voice”

A.Choice: Canada relied on the United Kingdom.

B.Choice: The United Kingdom relied on Canada.

C.Choice: Canada was more self-sufficient than the United Kingdom.

D.Choice: Canada and the United Kingdom did not communicate.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What does the usage of the word autonomous in the sentence below from paragraph 2 emphasize about Canada?
:ibox:“In short, he helped transform Canada from a colonial appendage to an autonomous state with a powerful voice and a sterling reputation.”

A.Choice: its dependence

B.Choice: its gratitude

C.Choice: its infamy

D.Choice: its independence

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How does paragraph 3 support the central idea?

A.Choice: It stresses Pearson's strength as a foreign policymaker.

B.Choice: It highlights Pearson's weaknesses in appearance and speech.

C.Choice: It compares Pearson to other prime ministers.

D.Choice: It quotes Pearson to emphasize the truth.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: How does the author reveal the shortcomings that contribute to Pearson's accomplishments being overlooked today?

A.Choice: by quoting Pearson in the book Lester B. Pearson

B.Choice: by mentioning Pearson's sense of humor and personality

C.Choice: by comparing Pearson to well-remembered, popular government leaders

D.Choice: by blaming it on the primitive technology in the 1960s

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which statement contradicts the idea that Lester B. Pearson was an important figure in Canadian history?

A.Choice: “Perhaps more than any Canadian leader in history, Pearson embodies a certain archetypal notion of what it means to be Canadian.”

B.Choice: “For better or worse, he popularized the idea of us as an understated, compassionate, peacemaking people—labels we're still negotiating four decades later.”

C.Choice: “Every time a teenager sets off to Europe with a Canadian flag sewn onto his backpack, it's because of him.”

D.Choice: “And every time a local is suddenly pleasant to the kid because of that flag, he has Lester B. Pearson to thank.”

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quote shows how Pearson contributed to the way foreign countries regard Canada?

A.Choice: “All of this after having already forged an ambitious career as a diplomat.”

B.Choice: “He spoke with a slight lisp. He wore horn-rimmed glasses, bow ties, and homburg hats.”

C.Choice: “The media, Cohen says, couldn't see that amid all the chaos and tumult and smoke and fire, Lester B. Pearson was quietly legislating.”

D.Choice: “And every time a local is suddenly pleasant to the kid because of that flag, he has Lester B. Pearson to thank.”

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which detail from the selection supports the theme?

A.Choice: “Every Wednesday was Dish Night at Wells Theater.”

B.Choice: “We heard about Pearl Harbor at a Sunday matinee.”

C.Choice: “This would be the movie of my life, this walking home under the moon from a movie with a girl holding a dinner plate under her arm like a book.”

D.Choice: “I came home and washed the dishes every night, and she stacked them away, bowls nesting in bowls as if we were moving the next day.”

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What does the collection of dishes at the Wells Theatre symbolize?

A.Choice: the beginning of a valuable collection

B.Choice: the beginning of a life together

C.Choice: the beginning of a disaster

D.Choice: the beginning of an economic downfall

SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech in context based on grade 8 reading and content.
Content: What is meant by “Business would pick up then” in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: The people would come to the theater only during certain times.

B.Choice: The theater would need to be moved to a new location.

C.Choice: The movie theater would begin to get a lot of customers.

D.Choice: The narrator and his girlfriend would come by all the time.

SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech in context based on grade 8 reading and content.
Content: How does the imagery in paragraph 3 impact the selection?

A.Choice: It shows the contrast of the Dish Night china, symbolizing innocence, with the broken china, symbolizing depression.

B.Choice: It shows china is very fragile and easily broken in the destruction caused by war.

C.Choice: It shows the contrast of the girlfriend's china, symbolizing peace, with the broken china, symbolizing war.

D.Choice: It shows china became a symbol of home for the narrator, because he wanted to return to his girlfriend.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What effect does the author create by using the description of the china in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: It creates a sense of longing.

B.Choice: It creates an atmosphere of hopelessness.

C.Choice: It establishes an air of suspense.

D.Choice: It establishes a feeling of loathing.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: How does the narrator's encounter with the broken china during the war affect him?

A.Choice: The narrator's experience with the broken dishes helps his memory.

B.Choice: The narrator's remembrances about the Wells Theatre become less meaningful.

C.Choice: The narrator's feelings about Dish Night begin to seem foolish.

D.Choice: The narrator's determination to return home gets stronger.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement summarizes the selection?

A.Choice: A young man in love walks his girlfriend home from the movies every Wednesday night after collecting a dish.

B.Choice: A young couple's connection to one another is developed through the practice of dish collecting.

C.Choice: After Pearl Harbor, a young man goes to Europe to fight in the war.

D.Choice: After the war, a young couple shop for more dishes to add to their collection.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which lines support the theme of the poem?

A.Choice: “When an apple tree's in blossom it is glorious to see, / But that's just a hint, at springtime, of the better things to be;”

B.Choice: “Architects of splendid vision long have labored on the earth, / And have raised their dreams in marble and we've marveled at their worth;”

C.Choice: “But I'm sure there's nothing finer for the eye of man to meet / Than an apple tree that's ready for the world to come and eat.”

D.Choice: “There's the promise of the apples, red and gleaming in the sun, / Like the medals worn by mortals as rewards for labors done;”

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which line supports the analysis that the speaker adores apple trees?

A.Choice: “There isn't any structure in the land that's 'got it beat.'”

B.Choice: “But that's just a hint, at springtime, of the better things to be;”

C.Choice: “The distant edge of summer; just a forecast of the treat”

D.Choice: “And have raised their dreams in marble and we've marveled at their worth;”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does “forecast” mean in line 11?

A.Choice: delay

B.Choice: estimate

C.Choice: desire

D.Choice: curiosity

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How do lines 13-18 support the theme of beauty in the poem?

A.Choice: by declaring that tall, exquisite buildings and gorgeous apples are costly

B.Choice: by describing how architects use marble in their designs

C.Choice: by comparing amazing architectural designs with an apple tree's attractiveness

D.Choice: by praising architects who design attractive buildings

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What can be inferred from lines 19-24?

A.Choice: The speaker wins awards for beautiful apples.

B.Choice: The speaker lacks interest in viewing or eating apples.

C.Choice: Apple trees grow in various shapes and sizes.

D.Choice: Apple trees produce beautiful apples for people to enjoy.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How do Mr. Wrenn's actions contribute to the development of the theme?

A.Choice: Mr. Wrenn's dislike of travel makes him nervous about meeting new people.

B.Choice: Mr. Wrenn's love of travel and adventure helps him to imagine a more exciting life.

C.Choice: Mr. Wrenn's dislike of the ticket taker causes him to miss the opportunity for a great experience.

D.Choice: Mr. Wrenn's love of socializing is more important than travel.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What can be inferred from paragraph 5?

A.Choice: The ticket taker is preoccupied; therefore, he neglects to present his normal smile.

B.Choice: The ticket taker is angry with Mr. Wrenn; therefore, he refuses to present his normal smile.

C.Choice: Mr. Wrenn is angry with the ticket taker; therefore, he refuses to acknowledge his smile.

D.Choice: Mr. Wrenn is preoccupied; therefore, he fails to notice the ticket taker.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: What do Mr. Wrenn's thoughts in paragraph 6 reveal about his view of the ticket taker?

A.Choice: Mr. Wrenn views himself as inferior to the ticket taker.

B.Choice: Mr. Wrenn views himself as superior to the ticket taker.

C.Choice: Mr. Wrenn views the ticket taker as an enemy.

D.Choice: Mr. Wrenn views the ticket taker as a close friend.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Which quote reveals Mr. Wrenn's timid nature?

A.Choice: “At thirty-four, Mr. Wrenn was the sales entry clerk of the Souvenir Company.”

B.Choice: “He was always bending over bills and columns of figures at a desk behind the stockroom.”

C.Choice: “He shook his head with the defiance of a cornered mouse, fussed with his mustache, and regarded the moving pictures gloomily.”

D.Choice: “Mr. Wrenn was really seeing, not cowpunchers and sagebrush, but himself, defying the office manager's meanness and revolting against the ticketman's rudeness.”

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the perspectives of the characters and the audience or reader create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: How does the perspective of Mr. Wrenn at the movie theater create irony in the selection?

A.Choice: Mr. Wrenn believes the ticket taker is rude, but the ticket taker is unaware that he has hurt Mr. Wrenn's feelings.

B.Choice: Mr. Wrenn believes the ticket taker is rude, and the ticket taker knowingly hurts Mr. Wrenn's feelings.

C.Choice: Mr. Wrenn imagines that he is traveling on an adventure with the ticket taker.

D.Choice: Mr. Wrenn imagines that he is traveling while paying for his ticket at the movie theater.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What does the author mean by “connoisseur of travel-pictures” in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: a person who is enthusiastic about movies filmed in other areas

B.Choice: a person who lacks interest in movies about other places

C.Choice: a person who is enthusiastic about traveling to see movies

D.Choice: a person who lacks interest in traveling to see movies

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the perspectives of the characters and the audience or reader create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: How do the different perspectives of the ticket taker and Mr. Wrenn affect the story?

A.Choice: The ticket taker's friendliness to the unfriendly Mr. Wrenn creates a tone of confusion.

B.Choice: The ticket taker's indifference to Mr. Wrenn's need for attention creates a tone of isolation.

C.Choice: The ticket taker's enjoyment of movies and Mr. Wrenn's indifference to them creates a tone of disappointment.

D.Choice: The ticket taker's commitment to his job compared to Mr. Wrenn's laziness creates a tone of unfairness and resentment.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement provides an objective summary of the selection?

A.Choice: A lonely man has a ticket taker as his one true friend. He has dreams of visiting faraway places with this friend.

B.Choice: A lonely man feels unappreciated at his job. He seeks an opportunity to advance his career by relocating to a different area.

C.Choice: A lonely man rents an apartment from a lady he views as a good friend. Although he likes where he lives, he longs for a better job.

D.Choice: A lonely man relies too much on a false sense of friendship. He wishes for a more fulfilling life to help him forget about his troubles.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “inaccessible” mean in the sentence below from paragraph 2?

:ibox:“As they rest during the day, concealed usually in the most inaccessible places they can find, and are seen only upon the wing, their power of flight is their most striking peculiarity in the popular mind, and it is perhaps no great wonder that by many people, both in ancient and modern times they have been regarded as birds.”

A.Choice: not possible to escape

B.Choice: present at night

C.Choice: difficult to reach

D.Choice: not visible on the surface

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which quote provides evidence to support the claim that the classification of bats is complex?

A.Choice: “Among the sounds which greet the ear of the wayfarer as the shades of evening deepen into night, one of the commonest is a rather faint chirping noise which comes mysteriously from overhead.”

B.Choice: “On looking up in search of the source of this peculiar sound, we may see a small, dark, shadow-like creature sweeping to and fro with great rapidity.”

C.Choice: “It is one of the curious groups of animals called bats, representatives of which are to be met with in all countries, always active at night or in the twilight, and presenting a remarkable general similarity of structure, although in some respects they may differ considerably in habits.”

D.Choice: “Nevertheless, their hairy bodies and leathery wings are so unlike anything that we ordinarily understand as pertaining to a bird, that opinion was apparently always divided, as to the true nature of these creatures—'a mouse with wings.'”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “systematist” mean in the sentence below from paragraph 2?

:ibox:“Nevertheless, their hairy bodies and leathery wings are so unlike anything that we ordinarily understand as pertaining to a bird, that opinion was apparently always divided, as to the true nature of these creatures—'a mouse with wings,' as Goldsmith called it once, according to James Boswell, is certainly a curious animal, and very difficult to classify so long as the would-be systematist has no particularly definite ideas to guide him.”

A.Choice: one who creates an order of categories

B.Choice: one who is considered an expert

C.Choice: one who interprets the meaning of words

D.Choice: one who studies animals

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: How does the last sentence in paragraph 2 refine a key concept about bats?

A.Choice: by describing how owls and bats fly at night

B.Choice: by explaining the functions of a bat's wings and its furry body

C.Choice: by showing how a bat is different from both a mouse and a bird

D.Choice: by illustrating how other languages have similar meanings for the word “bat”

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: How does paragraph 3 contribute to the development of the idea of scientific classification of bats?

A.Choice: It explains why classifying any sort of animal is important to its preservation.

B.Choice: It describes the specific characteristics that are used to classify bats as mammals.

C.Choice: It describes the specific characteristics that are used to understand that bats are alive.

D.Choice: It explains why classifying an animal as a mammal is better than classifying it as a bird.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events.
Content: How does the author distinguish bats from whales and dolphins in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: by conveying how difficult it is to classify bats, whales, and dolphins

B.Choice: by conveying how whales, dolphins, and manatees are considered fish

C.Choice: by showing how bats, whales, and dolphins nurse their babies with milk

D.Choice: by showing how the bat has more mammalian traits than whales and dolphins

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: Which statement reflects the author's point of view about the bat's abilities?

A.Choice: The author is puzzled as to why the bat is unable to be considered a bird.

B.Choice: The author is dismayed by the bat's comparison to a mouse.

C.Choice: The author is fascinated that the bat can both walk and fly.

D.Choice: The author is disturbed about the bat's ability to fly noiselessly.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement provides an objective summary of the text

A.Choice: Bats have been difficult animals to classify throughout history. A deeper understanding of the animals has led to their categorization as mammals that can fly like birds.

B.Choice: Bats have been studied extensively so that we can better understand their similarity to humans. This study is leading to treatments and cures for various diseases.

C.Choice: Bats are beautiful animals that are important to the global ecosystem. Efforts are being made to bring them back from the brink of extinction.

D.Choice: Bats are dangerous, bloodthirsty predators that spread rabies. Homes should be safeguarded against their inhabitation.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which quote supports the central idea that Hot Springs is a natural phenomenon?

A.Choice: “Americans believed the water springing to the surface in Hot Springs, Arkansas, was a death-defying elixir for the body and soul.”

B.Choice: “More than water enticed visitors in the early days; Mark claims some slick advertising played a role as well.”

C.Choice: “'One of the nineteenth-century writers who reported The Valley of Peace idea also reported volcanic activity here, which we know is not scientifically true.'”

D.Choice: “The warm splash of rain from 2400 BCE—traveling miles to get here—is hope enough.”

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: How does paragraph 3 refine a key concept in the text?

A.Choice: It provides an explanation of how the water is heated by outlining the difference between a geyser and the hot springs.

B.Choice: It suggests that the varying temperatures can be a health hazard by showing that the springs are very hot.

C.Choice: It shows that the area was once home to volcanic activity by outlining the difference between a geyser and the hot springs.

D.Choice: It provides an explanation on how water constantly pours from the sandstone of the hot springs.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which quote from the text is irrelevant to people's fascination with Hot Springs?

A.Choice: “For decades, Americans believed the water springing to the surface in Hot Springs, Arkansas, was a death-defying elixir for the body and soul.”

B.Choice: “Unlike the famed geysers of the West, these waters originate as rain and heat up largely through compression rather than volcanic activity.”

C.Choice: “As the liquid seeps deeper into the earth, it picks up trace minerals that many believe give it therapeutic power.”

D.Choice: “Legends were spread that the various American Indian tribes laid down their weapons here to share the healing waters in harmony.”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What is the meaning of “originate” in the sentence below from paragraph 3?
:ibox:“Park ranger Mark Blaeuer says that, unlike the famed geysers of the West, these waters originate as rain and heat up largely through compression rather than volcanic activity.”

A.Choice: start

B.Choice: remain

C.Choice: appear

D.Choice: change

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which detail from the text supports the analysis that the water from the springs is good for the mind and the body?

A.Choice: “Today people still bustle with excitement about getting into hot water.”

B.Choice: “As the liquid seeps deeper into the earth, it picks up trace minerals that many believe give it therapeutic power.”

C.Choice: “In the late 1800s, Americans trotted around the globe to resort spas for health and beauty remedies.”

D.Choice: “Perhaps Hot Springs can't deliver on the promise of peace and eternal youth.”

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events.
Content: Which quote supports the connection between water and the passage of time at Hot Springs?

A.Choice: “At an average 143 degrees, water constantly pours forth from the sandstone at the foot of Hot Springs Mountain.”

B.Choice: “According to geologists, after the rain falls, it slowly descends 6,000 to 8,000 feet, traveling only about one foot a year.”

C.Choice: “As the liquid seeps deeper into the earth, it picks up trace minerals that many believe give it therapeutic power.”

D.Choice: “Legends were spread that the various American Indian tribes laid down their weapons here to share the healing waters in harmony.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: How does the phrase “therapeutic power” in paragraph 5 affect the meaning of the text?

A.Choice: It suggests that the springs were used for health and beauty remedies.

B.Choice: It suggests that the springs were great for tourists.

C.Choice: It suggests that the springs pick up traces of minerals.

D.Choice: It suggests that the rain continues dropping another 6,000 to 8,000 feet after falling.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events.
Content: How does the author connect the American Indian tribes and the Spanish conquistadores in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: by explaining America's need to find peace in the 1870s

B.Choice: by conveying how the hot springs brought peace throughout history

C.Choice: by illustrating how advertisers used legends to attract visitors

D.Choice: by showing how some advertising methods worked better than others
